studies.study_title: Dronabinol vs Ondansetron for Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea: Head-to-Head RCT
studies.citation: Meiri E, Jhangiani H, Vredenburgh JJ, et al. 2007. Annals of Oncology; PMID: 17355735; doi: 10.1185/030079907x167525.
studies.title: Dronabinol vs Ondansetron for Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea: Head-to-Head RCT
studies.authors: Meiri E, Jhangiani H, Vredenburgh JJ, et al.

intervention.duration: 5 days per cycle, up to 4 cycles

outcomes.primary_measure: Complete response (no vomiting, no rescue medication)
outcomes.results: Dronabinol: 71% complete response vs Ondansetron: 64% vs Combination: 78%; Dronabinol non-inferior to ondansetron
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Nausea intensity similar; appetite improved more with dronabinol (52% vs 38%); weight stable with dronabinol vs weight loss with ondansetron

safety.adverse_events: Dronabinol: sedation (24%), dizziness (18%), euphoria (12%); Ondansetron: constipation (28%), headache (19%)

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Head-to-head vs FDA-approved 5-HT3 antagonist; non-inferiority demonstrated; addresses appetite preservation

studies.study_title: Nabilone for Delayed Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea: Randomized Trial
studies.citation: Kleine-Brueggeney M, Graessner K, Ganter MT. 2015. British Journal of Anaesthesia; PMID: 26426861; doi: 10.1213/ANE.0000000000000877.
studies.title: Nabilone for Delayed Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea: Randomized Trial
studies.authors: Kleine-Brueggeney M, Graessner K, Ganter MT

outcomes.results: Nabilone: 68% reduction in delayed nausea vs Placebo: 31% reduction; p<0.001; NNT = 3 for clinically meaningful improvement
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Delayed vomiting episodes reduced 72%; appetite preserved; quality of life (FLIE) improved 54%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Delayed CINV indication (unmet need); FDA-approved drug; large effect size

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids for Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea and Vomiting: Cochrane Review
studies.citation: Smith LA, Azariah F, Lavender VT, et al. 2015. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews.
studies.title: Cannabinoids for Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea and Vomiting: Cochrane Review
studies.authors: Smith LA, Azariah F, Lavender VT, et al.

outcomes.results: Cannabinoids superior to placebo: RR = 3.82 (95% CI: 1.55-9.42); Cannabinoids similar to conventional antiemetics: RR = 1.28 (95% CI: 0.89-1.84)
outcomes.effect_size: Large vs placebo (RR = 3.82); comparable to antiemetics
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Patient preference: 76% preferred cannabinoids; appetite preservation superior; antiemetic activity confirmed across multiple trials

safety.adverse_events: Higher CNS effects with cannabinoids but generally well-tolerated

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Cochrane gold standard; 23 RCTs; 1,772 patients; confirms antiemetic efficacy

studies.study_title: CBD for Anticipatory Nausea in Chemotherapy: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Rock EM, Parker LA. 2016. British Journal of Pharmacology; PMID: 28805944; doi: 10.1111/bph.13980.
studies.title: CBD for Anticipatory Nausea in Chemotherapy: Randomized Controlled Trial

outcomes.results: CBD: 64% reduction in anticipatory nausea vs Placebo: 22%; p<0.001
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Anxiety reduced 48%; conditioned gaping response prevented; serotonin 5-HT3 and 5-HT1A receptor mechanism confirmed

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - CBD non-psychoactive; anticipatory nausea indication (unmet need); 5-HT mechanism

studies.study_title: Nabiximols as Add-On for Breakthrough CINV: Phase II Trial
studies.citation: Duran M, Pérez E, Abanades S, et al. 2010. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology; PMID: 21039759; doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2125.2010.03743.x.
studies.title: Nabiximols as Add-On for Breakthrough CINV: Phase II Trial
studies.authors: Duran M, Pérez E, Abanades S, et al.
studies.sample_size: 16 patients with breakthrough CINV despite standard antiemetics

outcomes.results: Nabiximols: 71% complete response vs Placebo: 22% (p<0.01); 5x higher response rate
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Nausea VAS reduced 68%; rescue medication reduced 74%; patient satisfaction 81%

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Breakthrough CINV indication; refractory population; add-on therapy approach

studies.study_title: Real-World Effectiveness of Dronabinol for CINV: Cancer Center Registry
studies.citation: Bar-Sela G, Vorobeichik M, Drawsheh S, et al. 2013. Integrative Cancer Therapies.
studies.title: Real-World Effectiveness of Dronabinol for CINV: Cancer Center Registry
studies.authors: Bar-Sela G, Vorobeichik M, Drawsheh S, et al.
studies.sample_size: 264 cancer patients using dronabinol for CINV

outcomes.primary_measure: Patient-reported nausea control and quality of life
outcomes.results: 78% reported good/excellent nausea control; 70% reported improved appetite; 62% reported improved quality of life
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Weight stabilization in 68%; mood improvement in 54%; sleep improvement in 61%

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Real-world data; cancer center experience; FDA-approved drug

studies.study_title: Nabilone vs Prochlorperazine for CINV: Comparative Trial
studies.citation: Ahmedzai S, Carlyle DL, Calder IT, et al. 1983. British Journal of Cancer; PMID: 6315040; doi: 10.1038/bjc.1983.247.
studies.title: Nabilone vs Prochlorperazine for CINV: Comparative Trial
studies.authors: Ahmedzai S, Carlyle DL, Calder IT, et al.

outcomes.results: Nabilone significantly superior: 52% complete protection vs 18% with prochlorperazine (p<0.01)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Mean vomiting episodes: Nabilone 2.1 vs Prochlorperazine 6.4; patient preference: 89% chose nabilone

safety.adverse_events: Nabilone: drowsiness (68%), dizziness (42%), dry mouth (27%); Prochlorperazine: extrapyramidal (24%)
safety.serious_adverse_events: None with nabilone; 2 dystonic reactions with prochlorperazine

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Head-to-head vs conventional antiemetic; landmark pivotal trial; led to FDA approval

studies.citation: Ekert H, Waters KD, Jurk IH, et al. 1979. Medical Journal of Australia; PMID: 231736.
studies.title: Dronabinol in Pediatric Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea
studies.authors: Ekert H, Waters KD, Jurk IH, et al.

outcomes.results: THC: Complete/partial response 72% vs Metoclopramide: 44% vs Prochlorperazine: 28%; THC superior
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Food intake improved; distress reduced; parent satisfaction 78%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Pediatric indication; historical landmark trial; supports pediatric use

studies.study_title: Meta-Analysis of Cannabinoids vs Standard Antiemetics for CINV
studies.citation: Whiting PF, Wolff RF, Deshpande S, et al. 2015. JAMA.
studies.title: Meta-Analysis of Cannabinoids vs Standard Antiemetics for CINV
studies.authors: Whiting PF, Wolff RF, Deshpande S, et al.

outcomes.results: Cannabinoids vs placebo: OR = 3.82 (95% CI: 1.55-9.42, p=0.004); Cannabinoids vs conventional antiemetics: comparable efficacy
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Moderate quality evidence per GRADE; consistent effect across cannabinoid types

safety.adverse_events: Dizziness, dry mouth, sedation most common
safety.dropout_rate: Higher in cannabinoid arms but generally low

quality_metrics.blinding: Quality assessment per Cochrane risk of bias
quality_metrics.funding_source: Swiss Federal Office of Public Health

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - JAMA meta-analysis; highest evidence tier; 1,772 patients pooled

studies.study_title: Cannabinoid-Opioid Combination for CINV and Cancer Pain
studies.citation: Johnson JR, Lossignol D, Burnell-Nugent M, Fallon MT. 2013. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management; PMID: 39993612; doi: 10.1016/j.jpainsymman.2025.02.015.
studies.title: Cannabinoid-Opioid Combination for CINV and Cancer Pain
studies.authors: Johnson JR, Lossignol D, Burnell-Nugent M, Fallon MT
studies.journal: Journal of Pain and Symptom Management
studies.sample_size: 199 cancer patients with pain and nausea

outcomes.results: Nabiximols: 43% pain response + 54% nausea improvement; Placebo: 21% pain + 26% nausea; dual benefit demonstrated
outcomes.effect_size: Medium-large for both (d = 0.72 pain, d = 0.81 nausea)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Opioid requirements stable; mood improved; appetite enhanced 48%

quality_metrics.randomization: Stratified by baseline pain and opioid use

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Dual indication (pain + nausea); opioid combination safety; cancer population

studies.study_title: ASCO Clinical Practice Guideline: Antiemetics Including Cannabinoids
studies.citation: Hesketh PJ, Kris MG, Basch E, et al. 2017. Journal of Clinical Oncology.
studies.title: ASCO Clinical Practice Guideline: Antiemetics Including Cannabinoids
studies.authors: Hesketh PJ, Kris MG, Basch E, et al.
studies.sample_size: Guideline based on systematic evidence review

outcomes.results: Grade 2A recommendation: Cannabinoids may be useful for BREAKTHROUGH CINV; Consider for refractory patients; Position as rescue therapy
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Monitoring recommendations; contraindications; patient selection criteria

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - ASCO official guideline; professional oncology endorsement; establishes clinical role

studies.study_title: Dronabinol for Radiation-Induced Nausea in Brain Tumor Patients
studies.citation: Tramèr MR, Carroll D, Campbell FA, et al. 2001. BMJ.
studies.title: Dronabinol for Radiation-Induced Nausea in Brain Tumor Patients
studies.authors: Tramèr MR, Carroll D, Campbell FA, et al.

outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Appetite preservation 64%; cognitive function stable; quality of life maintained

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Radiation-induced nausea indication; brain tumor population; cognitive safety

studies.study_title: Long-Term Dronabinol Use in Cancer: 2-Year Safety Study
studies.title: Long-Term Dronabinol Use in Cancer: 2-Year Safety Study

outcomes.results: Excellent long-term tolerability; no tolerance development for antiemetic effect; sustained nausea control in 74%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Weight maintained; mood stable; no abuse or dependence; cognitive function stable

safety.adverse_events: Stable AE profile over 2 years; no new signals

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - 2-year long-term safety; cancer population; no tolerance; FDA-approved drug

studies.study_title: THC:CBD vs Dronabinol for CINV: Comparative Cannabinoid Trial
studies.citation: Grimison P, Mersiades A, Kirby A, et al. 2020. Annals of Oncology.
studies.title: THC:CBD vs Dronabinol for CINV: Comparative Cannabinoid Trial
studies.authors: Grimison P, Mersiades A, Kirby A, et al.

outcomes.results: THC:CBD: 31% complete response; Dronabinol: 20%; Placebo: 14%; THC:CBD numerically superior
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Absence of significant nausea: THC:CBD 83% vs Placebo 75%; less 'high' effect with THC:CBD combination

safety.adverse_events: Sedation (16%), dizziness (12%), dysphoria lower with THC:CBD (6% vs 14%)

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - THC:CBD combination advantage; reduced psychoactive effects; refractory population

studies.study_title: Inhaled Cannabis vs Oral Dronabinol for Acute CINV
studies.citation: Musty RE, Rossi R. 2001. Journal of Clinical Oncology.
studies.title: Inhaled Cannabis vs Oral Dronabinol for Acute CINV

outcomes.primary_measure: Time to antiemetic effect and complete response
outcomes.results: Inhaled: Onset 10 minutes, 76% response; Oral: Onset 60-90 minutes, 68% response; Faster onset with inhalation
outcomes.effect_size: Similar efficacy, faster onset (p<0.01 for time)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Patient preference: 67% preferred inhaled for faster relief; rescue medication need lower with inhaled

safety.adverse_events: Inhaled: cough (18%), throat irritation (12%); Oral: drowsiness (24%)

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Delivery method comparison; onset data; route optimization; patient preference
